text: I didn’t run out.
The wind and snow were too fierce, the shield wall too tight, the Demon King too close—every reason weighed on my chest like a stone, forcing me to swallow that step back down.
I told myself: she said ‘Don’t move.’ She said ‘Hold your ground.’ If I didn’t cause trouble, that alone was helping.
But I knew too—those were just excuses I was giving my fear.
Alicia held the necklace in her hand. The pendant burned bright in the black light, like a piece of metal heated red-hot.
Sensing ‘termination,’ the black mist surged violently, like a tide crashing toward her wrist.
Her fingers trembled once—not fear, but exhaustion pressing down for a single heartbeat.
That was the moment. That was the moment I did nothing.
The Demon King’s voice layered countless whispers together: “Come—back—.”
The sound scraped against bone. The black mist tightened as if obeying a command, wrapping around her wrist, her ankles, her throat.
Alicia’s breathing grew shallow. She didn’t look back at me. She only steadied her sword point more firmly at the core.
She tried to force the necklace in. But the mist had already coiled around the pendant—like a living thing biting down on prey and refusing to let go.
She pushed, knuckles turning white, the veins on the back of her hand swelling. The pendant advanced half an inch—then was dragged back, brutally.
The Demon King’s claw pressed down. It wasn’t an attack—it was like it meant to ‘press her back.’ Back into the rift, back into the loop, back onto the old rails of fate.
Alicia raised her arm to block. Her knees sank hard; the snow collapsed into a deep crater. Her shoulder guard burst, blood seeping along her bracer and dripping onto the snow, turning it dark.
She still stepped forward—forcing herself closer. She was always like this: trading life for an opening.
But this time, no one stole that half second for her.
The black mist suddenly recoiled, like countless icy chains binding her throat and limbs. Her body was yanked up, hung in front of the core.
Her sword fell into the snow with a dull thud.
That sound finally made me understand: I was still standing—and she was losing everything.
Alicia’s lips moved. She seemed to want to say something—maybe an order for me to fall back, maybe… a farewell she’d finally have time to speak.
But the black mist cut off every word. Her eyes were still bright—until their focus began to slip away.
The Demon King pressed her toward the rift. It wasn’t tearing—it was erasure: like wiping a person clean out of the world.
In the next second, Alicia’s figure was swallowed by black light, along with the necklace—vanishing so completely it was as if she had never been there.
The wind went still for a heartbeat. Not because the wind had stopped—because my world had.
I wanted to run out, but my legs were filled with lead. Something clogged my throat; all I could manage was a broken, ragged breath.
Someone behind the shield wall was shouting, someone tried to pull me back—but I couldn’t hear them.
The barrier’s blue light began to splinter, breaking into shard after shard like glass. The soldiers’ breathing turned into panicked, ragged gasps.
The core in the Demon King’s chest lit up again. The light was terrifyingly steady, as if proclaiming: the loop continues.
Black mist spread into a tide, rolling over the snow and swallowing the shield line. The city wall groaned as if it were breaking.
A cold emptiness flooded my chest, like the world had sentenced me to death. As darkness swallowed my vision, I had only one thought left—I didn’t save her. I didn’t even try.
